content.text: The width of one strip is \(56\mathrm{mm}\). There are 40 staples in the strip
Calculate the average width of **one** staple
average width of **one** staple =   .........  mm
A student wants to find the volume of one strip of 40 staples. The student has a measuring cylinder and a beaker of water as shown in Fig. 1.2
The staples are made from a block of metal
The mass of the block is \(296\mathrm{g}\). The volume of the block is \(33.2\mathrm{cm}^3\)
Calculate the density of the metal. Include the unit
density of the metal =   .........  unit   .........
Fig. 1.1 shows two strips of staples
NOT to scale
Use the graph to determine the length of the spring when the student adds a load of \(8.0 \text{N}\) to the spring
length of spring =   .........  cm
Use the graph to determine the load added to the spring when the extension of the spring is \(7.0 \text{cm}\)
load for an extension of \(7.0 \text{cm} =\)   .........  N
A student has a spring of length \(14.0 \text{cm}\). She stretches the spring by adding different loads to the spring
She measures the length of the spring for each load. She plots a graph of the results
Fig. 2.1 shows the graph of her results
Complete the sentence about effects of forces. Choose a word from the box
A load stretching a spring is an example of a force changing the size and the
1 of an object
A clamp stand used in the experiment has a weight of 8.6 N
Calculate the mass of the clamp stand
mass of clamp stand =   .........  \(kg\)
Calculate the speed of the cyclist in section PQ
Describe the motion of the cyclist in section QR on the graph
Fig. 3.2 shows a bicycle fitted with wide tyres and a bicycle fitted with narrow tyres. The two bicycles have the same weight
People use bicycles fitted with wide tyres to ride over soft ground
Explain why people use bicycles fitted with wide tyres to ride over soft ground. Use your ideas about pressure
Fig. 3.1 shows the distance-time graph for a cyclist
The journey has two sections, PQ and QR
Describe the movement of the gas particles
Describe how the gas particles exert a pressure on the walls of the cylinder and piston
The piston in Fig. 4.1 moves to the left
The volume of the gas decreases. The temperature of the gas does not change
State and explain any change in the pressure of the gas when the piston moves to the left
Fig. 4.1 shows some gas, at room temperature, in a cylinder with a piston that can move. The gas cannot escape from the cylinder
Fig. 5.1 shows a child pulling a toy trolley across the floor
The child pulls the toy trolley with a horizontal force of \(12\mathrm{N}.\) The distance moved by the trolley is \(5.0\mathrm{m}\)
Calculate the mechanical work done on the toy trolley by the \(12\mathrm{N}\) force
mechanical work done =   .........  J
Fig. 5.2 shows a candle burning
Fig. 5.2
Describe the energy transfers taking place as the candle burns
Your answer should refer to energy stores as well as transfers between energy stores
This question is about work, energy stores and energy transfers
Determine the amplitude of the wave in Fig. 6.1
amplitude =   .........  \(cm\)
Determine the frequency of the wave in Fig. 6.1
frequency =   .........  \(Hz\)
Describe the motion of particles in a transverse water wave
A wave has a frequency of 400 Hz and a wavelength of 0.90 m
Calculate the velocity of the wave
velocity =   .........  \(m/s\)
Fig. 6.1 shows how the displacement of a transverse wave varies with time
A student places a book in front of a plane mirror
State **three** characteristics of the image of the book formed by the plane mirror
Give **one** use of ultraviolet radiation
Give **one** possible harmful effect of excessive exposure to ultraviolet radiation
Visible light is one region of the electromagnetic spectrum. Another region is ultraviolet radiation
A student uses a dry cloth to rub a plastic rod
State how the plastic rod gains a positive charge from friction between the cloth and the rod
Three balls, P, Q and R, are electrically charged. The balls are suspended by threads of insulating material. Fig. 8.1 shows the arrangement
The charge on ball P is positive
State the charge on ball Q and the charge on ball R
ball Q
ball R
The student connects ball P to earth with a copper wire. Charges from the earth flow in the copper wire to ball P
State the name of the electrically charged particles moving in the copper wire
The power input of the kettle is \(1.5 \text{kW}\). The potential difference of the mains electrical supply for the kettle is \(220 \text{V}\)
Calculate the current in the kettle when it is switched on
current in kettle =   .........  A
The \(1.5 \text{kW}\) kettle is used for a total of 4.0 hours. The cost of \(1.0 \text{kWh}\) of electrical energy is 14 pennies (p)
Calculate the cost of the energy used by the kettle in 4.0 hours
cost of energy =   .........  p
Fig. 9.2 shows an overloaded extension lead
Explain the danger of connecting too many plugs to an extension lead
Fig. 9.1 shows an electric kettle
Fig. 10.1 shows two coils of wire P and Q, each in a circuit. The ends of the coils are close but not touching
Now, switch S is closed. The pointer in the sensitive ammeter G deflects and then returns to its zero position
Explain why the pointer in sensitive ammeter G deflects
Describe the construction of a step-up transformer. You may draw a labelled diagram as part of your answer
Determine the number of:
protons in one nucleus of americium-241,
neutrons in one nucleus of americium-241
Americium-241 has a half-life of 430 years
A radioactive source contains \(12\mathrm{mg}\) of americium-241
Calculate the mass of americium-241 that remains in the source after 860 years
mass of americium-241 remaining =   .........  mg
Americium-241 is a radioactive nuclide. The nuclide notation for a nucleus of americium-241 is
State, in order, the names of the **three** planets closest to the Sun
Closest to the Sun
Furthest from the Sun
Define a light-year
Jupiter is \(780000000000 \text{m}\) ( \(7.8 \times 10^{11} \text{m}\) ) from the Sun
The speed of light is \(300000000 \text{m / s}\) ( \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m / s}\) )
Calculate the time for light to travel from the Sun to Jupiter
